http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=E4BD7C05-EA0E-49C7-9BDD-ABB496CA87CA&displaylang=en

A restart is required after applying the patch.

Title: Microsoft Help and Support Center HCP Buffer Overflow Lets Remote and Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Local Computer Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Help and Support Center function supplied with Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.  A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.  A local user can also execute arbitrary code with System privileges.
It is reported that a file used by the HCP protocol contains a buffer overflow.  The flaw reportedly resides in the Help Service (helpsvc.exe), which is started by svchost.exe.

A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code in the Local Computer security zone.  A local user can also execute arbitrary code with System privileges.

Microsoft reports that the vulnerable code is included in all supported Windows operating systems, but the HCP protocol is only supported on Windows XP and 2003.

Microsoft has assigned a "Critical" severity rating for this flaw on Windows XP and Windows Server 2003 and a "Low" severity rating for the other affected platforms.

Microsoft credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Ltd. with reporting this flaw.
Impact':
A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded, will execute arbitrary code in the Local Computer zone.

A local user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution:
The following patches are available:

Microsoft Windows Millennium Edition

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=7D6F4228-0E31-4F46-9795-5CDD566BB3B8&displaylang=en

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=8B990946-84C8-4C91-899C-5A44EC13174E&displaylang=en

A restart is required after applying this patch.

Title: Microsoft Windows Messenger Service Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Local System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Windows Messenger Service (part of the Windows operating system).  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
It is reported that the Messenger Service does not properly validate the length of a message when allocating a buffer for the message. A remote user can reportedly create a specially crafted message that will execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges.

Microsoft reports that messages are delivered to the Messenger service via NetBIOS or RPC.

Microsoft credits the Last Stage of Delirium Research Group with reporting this flaw.

[Editor's note:  The Windows Messenger Service is not related to the Windows Messenger or MSN Messenger applications.]
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches:

Microsoft Windows NT Workstation 4.0, Service Pack 6a

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=7597FCF4-6615-4074-9E46-A17D808ED38D&displaylang=en

Title: Microsoft Windows Troubleshooter ActiveX Control Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Local Troubleshooter ActiveX control (Tshoot.ocx) on Windows 2000.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.
Parameters provided to the control are not properly validated in certain cases, the report said.  A remote user can create HTML that will invoke the ActiveX control and trigger the buffer overflow, executing arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.  This control is marked "safe for scripting", according to the vendor.

Microsoft credits Greg Jones of KPMG UK and Cesar Cerrudo for reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
A patch is available:

Microsoft Windows 2000, Service Pack 2

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=FC1FD84B-B3A4-43F5-804B-A2608EC56163&displaylang=en

Microsoft Windows 2000, Service Pack 3, Service Pack 4

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=48D16574-9B17-463B-A5D2-D75BA5128EF9&displaylang=en

A reboot is required after installing this patch.

Title: Microsoft Authenticode Low Memory Flaw May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Authenticode, affecting several Microsoft operating system platforms.  A remote user may be able to install and execute an ActiveX control on the target user's system.
It is reported that a remote user can create HTML that, under certain low memory conditions, can download and install an ActiveX control without requesting permission from the target user.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

According to the report, Windows Me is not affected.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target user's system with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches:

Microsoft Windows NT Workstation 4.0, Service Pack 6a

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=921466F5-BC40-4E8E-BB57-6B81B57C21B6&displaylang=en

Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0, Service Pack 6a

Microsoft Windows 2000, Service Pack 2

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=90D27AEC-7D2A-45FD-B85A-E98E574338F1&displaylang=en

Microsoft Windows Server 2003

This patch requires a restart.

Title: Microsoft Windows RPC Multi-threaded Race Condition Lets Remote Users Crash the Service or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Windows 2000, XP, 2003
Description:
A race condition vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Windows in the Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service.  A remote user can cause the RPC service to crash or execute arbitrary code.
Internet Security Systems (ISS) reproted that there is a multi-threaded race condition in the processing of incoming RPC requests. Due to a flaw in the software, two separate threads may attempt to process the same incoming RPC request.  One of the threads may free the memory allocated to hold the incoming packet before the other thread is finished processing the packet.  As a result, a memory error may occur.

A remote user can send specially crafted packets to the target system to cause the target RPC service to crash.  It may also be possible to cause the target system to reboot, according to the report.  ISS says that thousands of packets may be required to trigger the flaw.

eEye Digital Security later reported that a remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.

Systems patched with the MS03-039 patch are vulnerable, the report said.

ISS warned that ports 135, 137, 138, 139, 445, 593 may be used as attack vectors in exploiting this vulnerability.

ISS also clarified that some reports have incorrectly suggested that this flaw is a variant of the flaw described in MS03-039.

The vendor was reportedly notified on October 13, 2003.

eEye Digital Security later reported that the vendor was notified by eEye of the same (or very similar) flaw on September 10, 2003.
Impact':
A remote user can cause the target RPC service to crash.

A remote user may be able to cause the target system to crash.

A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows OS PostThreadMessage() API Permits Local Users to Terminate Processes That Have Message Queues
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows operating system in the PostThreadMessage() API.  A local user can terminate arbitrary processes in certain cases.
Security-Assessment.com reported that a local user of any privilege level can send a WM_QUIT message to an arbitrary process that has a message queue to cause the target process to terminate.

The report indicates that in some cases, a local user can also send WM_DESTROY or WM_CLOSE messages to cause a target process to terminate.

In some cases, it is possible to bypass shutdown requirements, such as password authentication requirements, the report said.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a target process that has a message queue to terminate.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows Remote Procedure Call (RPC) DCOM Activation Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in several Microsoft operating systems in the RPCSS service related to Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) messages.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges or cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the RPCSS service contains several vulnerabilities in the processing of RPC DCOM object activation requests that can be triggered by a remote user sending malformed messages.

It is reported that a remote user can establish a connection to the target system and then send a specially crafted and malformed RPC message to cause the DCOM activation infrastructure to execute arbitrary, user-supplied code.  This is because user-supplied inputs are not properly checked by the software, according to the report.  The flaws reportedly occur in the processing of RPC DCOM object activation requests.

Some of the vulnerabilities can be exploited to execute arbitrary code.  Another vulnerability results in the RPCSS service crashing and only affects Windows 2000.

Internet Security Systems separately reported that there is a buffer overflow in the Message Queue Manager on Windows 2000 [CVE: CVE-2003-0995].  A remote user can reportedly send a specially-crafted queue registration request to trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code on the system with Local System privileges.

Microsoft reports that the affected service may initially receive connections via UDP ports 135, 137, 138, and 445 and TCP ports 135, 139, 445, and 593.  In addition, the systems can be configured to receive RPC connections via TCP on 80 and 443.  Other ports may also be used.

One of these buffer overflow vulnerabilities is related to the exploit code released by XFocus on July 25, 2003 and described in Alert ID 1007302 [the exploit was also reportedly effective against CVE CVE-2003-0352].

Technical details regarding another of the buffer overflow vulnerabilities has been provided by eEye Digital Security [see the Message History for a separate Alert dedicated to the eEye advisory].  In this particular buffer overflow, a remote user can reportedly send a DCERPC "bind" packet followed by a malformed DCERPC DCOM object activation request packet.  The activate packet can contain specially crafted length fields to cause heap memory to be overwritten with user-supplied data, the report said.  It may require several activation packets (e.g., 4, 5) to cause the memory to be overwritten.

Microsoft credits eEye Digital Security, NSFOCUS Security Team, and Xue Yong Zhi and Renaud Deraison from Tenable Network Security with reporting these flaws.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges on the target server.  A remote user can cause the target server's RPCSS service to crash.
Solution:
Microsoft has released the following patches:

The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP2, SP3, or SP4.  The Windows XP patch can be installed on Windows XP Gold or SP1.  The Windows Server 2003 patch can be installed on Windows Server 2003 Gold.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in Windows 2000 SP5, Windows XP SP2, and Windows Server 2003 SP1.

A reboot is required after installing this patch.

Title: Microsoft Windows NetBIOS Name Service May Disclose Memory Contents to Remote Users
Version(s): Windows NT 4.0 , NT 4.0 TSE, 2000, XP, and 2003
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in several Microsoft Windows operating systems in the NetBIOS implementation.  The system may leak data from random memory locations to remote users.
It is reported that the NetBIOS Name Service (NBNS) may, under certain conditions, respond to a query with valid response data plus some random data from the target system's memory.  A remote user can send a query to UDP port 137 and monitor the response.  In some cases where padding is required in the response packet, the system may fail to properly pad the packet.  This may occur because the buffer created for a NBNS reply is not initialized before the buffer is used.

According to the report, the remote user cannot control what information is disclosed.  However, a remote user can generate a large number of queries to attempt to retrieve a larger amount of random memory contents.  The vendor states that the typical padding size per packet is 15 bytes or less.

According to the vendor, Windows ME is not affected.

Microsoft credits Mike Price of Foundstone Labs for reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can query the NetBIOS Name Service port and monitor the response to view a small, random portion of the target system's memory.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following fixes:

* Windows Server 2003

Title: (Vendor Issues Worm Alert) Re: Microsoft Windows Remote Procedure Call (RPC) Service Buffer Overflow in Processing DCOM Requests Allows Remote Code Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): NT 4.0, NT 4.0 Terminal Services Edition, Windows 2000, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service implementation. A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.  Microsoft has issued a PSS Security Response Team Alert regarding the W32.Blaster.worm that is actively exploiting this vulnerability.
A remote user can reportedly send a malformed Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) object activation request to the target server to cause arbitrary code to be executed. The code will run with Local System privileges, according to the report.

Microsoft notes that the bug does not reside in the RPC endpoint mapper (which listens on that port), but rather, the bug resides in a low level DCOM interface. Microsoft credits The Last Stage of Delirium Research Group with reporting this flaw.

On August 11, 2003, the security community noticed that the "Blaster" worm had started exploiting this vulnerability on a significant number of systems.  The worm scans random IP addresses looking for vulnerable systems running on TCP port 135.  If the worm finds a vulnerable system, the worm executes code on the target system.  The code then downloads and executes the "msblast.exe" file via TFTP.  This creates the following Windows registry key:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run "windows auto update" = msblast.exe I just want to say LOVE YOU SAN!! bill

Infected systems may reboot every minute or so.  However, some infected systems will appear to operate normally.

To determine whether your system has been infected, you can search for a "msblast.exe" file in the WINDOWS SYSTEM32 directory.

Microsoft has provided the following reference links from various anti-virus software vendors for more information on the worm and how to repair an infected system:

http://us.mcafee.com/virusInfo/default.asp?id=description&virus_k=100547
http://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/virusencyclo/default5.asp?VName=WORM_MSBLAST.A
http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.blaster.worm.html
http://www3.ca.com/virusinfo/virus.aspx?ID=36265

To protect against this worm, Microsoft says that you should block TCP ports 135, 139, 445 and 593 to protect the RPC service, as well as UDP 69 (TFTP)and TCP 4444 to prevent some worm-related communications.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with Local System privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following fixes:

* Windows NT 4.0 Server

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=6C0F0160-64FA-424C-A3C1-C9FAD2DC65CA&displaylang=en

* Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=2CC66F4E-217E-4FA7-BDBF-DF77A0B9303F&displaylang=en

* Windows 2000

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=C8B8A846-F541-4C15-8C9F-220354449117&displaylang=en

* Windows XP 32 bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=2354406C-C5B6-44AC-9532-3DE40F69C074&displaylang=en

* Windows XP 64 bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=1B00F5DF-4A85-488F-80E3-C347ADCC4DF1&displaylang=en

* Windows Server 2003 32 bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=F8E0FF3A-9F4C-4061-9009-3A212458E92E&displaylang=en

* Windows Server 2003 64 bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=2B566973-C3F0-4EC1-995F-017E35692BC7&displaylang=en

The Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on SP6a.  The Windows NT 4.0, Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on Windows NT 4.0, Terminal Server Edition SP6.  The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP3 or SP4.  The Windows XP patch can be installed on Windows XP Gold or SP1.  The Windows Server 2003 patch can be installed on systems running Windows Server 2003 Gold.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in Windows 2000 SP5, Windows XP SP2, and Windows Server 2003 SP1.

A reboot is required after installing this fix.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 823980 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com?kbid=823980

Microsoft describes several workaround steps, including disabling DCOM.  For workaround instructions, refer to the Vendor URL.

Version(s): Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 Server, NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition
Impact': A remote or local user can cause denial of service conditions in applications on Windows NT that use the affected function.  The exact nature of the impact depends on how the application is designed and implemented.

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Shell Buffer Overflow in Processing Folder Display Attributes Permits Remote Code Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): XP SP1
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Windows XP in the Windows shell.  A remote authenticated user or a local user can cause a target user to execute arbitrary code.
It is reported that a function used by the Windows shell to extract custom display attributes from directories contains a buffer overflow.  A local user or a remote authenticated user can reportedly create a 'desktop.ini' file that contains a specially crafted custom attribute.  Then, when the target user views a folder containing this file (for example, on a network share), arbitrary code contained in the file may be executed by the target user with the privileges of the target user.

According to Microsoft, this flaw only affects Windows XP SP1.  [Editor's note:  It appears that it may also affect Windows XP without SP1, but the vendor was not clear on this.  We have asked for clarification.]
Impact': A local user or a remote authenticated user can cause the target user to execute arbitrary code when viewing a folder containing a malicious 'desktop.ini' file.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following fixes:

* Microsoft Windows XP 32 bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=27D02AF5-A2E1-4E25-9D16-502886161A35&displaylang=en

* Microsoft Windows XP 64 bit Edition 

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=4BA84E2B-49F9-4416-8745-51F03503AB7D&displaylang=en

This patch can be installed on Windows XP SP1.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in Windows XP SP2.

A reboot is reportedly required after installing this patch.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 821557 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support site:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;[LN];821557
