Title: Microsoft Windows Operating System Certificate Enrollment ActiveX Control Allows Remote Users to Delete Certificates on a Target User's System
Description:
Microsoft reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Certificate Enrollment Control, an ActiveX control provided in all versions of the Windows operating system.  A remote user could create HTML that, when loaded by a target user, would delete certificates on the target user's system.
According to the report, this ActiveX control is used to submit PKCS #10 compliant certificate requests, and after receiving the requested certificate, stores it in the user's local certificate store.

The flaw lets remote users access certificates that are already installed on the user's system.  No further details were provided regarding the nature of the flaw.

Microsoft also reports that there is a similar but "less serious" vulnerability in the SmartCard Enrollment ActiveX control shipped with Windows 2000 and Windows XP.  However, this flaw reportedly cannot be used to delete smart card-based certificates.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a "Critical" severity rating for Client Systems.
Impact': A remote user could delete certificates on a target user's system.  A remote user could delete or corrupt trusted root certificates, EFS encryption certificates, email-signing certificates, and any other certificates on the system, creating a denial of service condition.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches, as listed below.  Also, patches will be available from Windows Update on August 29, 2002.

For Microsoft Windows 98:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows98/downloads/contents/WUCritical/q323172/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows 98 Second Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows98/downloads/contents/WUCritical/q323172/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows Me:

http://download.microsoft.com/download/WINME/PATCH/24421/WINME/EN-US/323172USAM.EXE

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41747

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0, Terminal Server Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41361

Microsoft Windows 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41568

Microsoft Windows XP:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41598

Microsoft Windows XP 64-bit Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41598

The Windows 98 patch can be installed on any system running Windows 98.  The Windows 98 Second Edition patch can be installed on any system running Windows 98 SE.  The Windows Me patch can be installed on any system running Windows Me.  The Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 SP6a.  The Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition SP6. The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP1 or Windows 2000 SP2.  The patch for Windows XP can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold.

Microsoft reports that the fix for this issue is already included in Windows XP SP1 and will be included in Windows 2000 SP4.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q323172 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

See the Microsoft knowledge base article for some important caveats.  Apparently, the patch will disable the control when installed on systems running versions of Internet Explorer prior to version 5.  Also, web sites that use the Certificate Enrollment Control will require minor code changes to operate with the new control.

Title: Microsoft Operating System SMB Protocol Implementation in the Network
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Windows NT 4.0, 2000, and XP
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Server Message Block (SMB) protocol implementation.  A remote user could cause the target system to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed (but this has not been confirmed).
A remote user with network access to port 139 and/or 445 on the target host can send a specially crafted SMB request to the target host to cause the target host to crash.  This can be achieved with anonymous account access or with a valid user account.  If the system administrator has disabled anonymous access on the target host, then the remote user must be authenticated to commit the attack.

Microsoft notes that it may be possible to execute arbitrary code via this method, but that has not been confirmed.

Microsoft has assigned a Severity Rating of 'Low' for Internet Servers and 'Moderate' for Intranet Servers and Client Systems.

Microsoft credits Alberto Solino and Hernan Ochoa of the Security Consulting Services team of Core Security Technologies for reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target host to crash.  It may also be possible for a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the target host, but that has not been confirmed.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches.

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41493

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41519

For Microsoft Windows 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41468

For Microsoft Windows XP:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41524

For Microsoft Windows XP 64 bit Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41549

Microsoft notes that the Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on NT 4.0 SP6a.  The NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on NT 4.0 TSE SP6.  The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP2 SP3.  The patch for XP can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in Windows 2000 SP4 and Windows XP SP1.

Microsoft plans to issued Knowledge Base article Q326830 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Title: Microsoft NTFS Filesystem in Windows NT and Windows 2000 Has Auditing Hole That Lets Local Users Access Files Without the File Access Being Audited
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's NTFS filesystem.  A local user could exploit this flaw to avoid being audited while accessing files.
A local user can create a hard link to an existing file on the disk.  According to a report by @stake, the auditing mechanism of Windows NT and Windows 2000 does not properly track hard links and produces some 'erroneous results'.  A local user can access a linked file through a hard link so that the name of the true file being accessed does not appear in the security event log.  The file name of the hard link will appear in the event log, but the hard link can be deleted after the file has been accessed, removing any trace of the file access activity.

Some demonstration exploit transcripts are provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can access a file without the file access being audited.
Solution:
A fix is available in Windows 2000 SP3.  XP and .Net server beta were fixed before they shipped.

According to @stake, the solution was to create a new "Hard link creation attempt" audit event.  This creates a audit entry that connects the new hard link file name to the target file name. 

The audit entry looks like this:

Event Type:	Success Audit
Event Source:	Security
Event Category:	Object Access 
Event ID:	568
Date:		8/5/2002
Time:		6:29:32 PM
User:		DOMAIN\user
Computer:	COMPUTER
Description:
Hard link creation attempt:
Primary User Name:	user
Primary Domain:	DOMIAN
Primary Logon ID:	(0x0,0xFF10)
File Name:	C:\audited\foo.txt
Link Name:	C:\temp\link.txt

According to the report, a tool has also been created to search for hard links that already exist on the system prior to installing SP3. This is recommended if you are auditing sensitive files on a system that has multiple user access.

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/techinfo/reskit/tools/new/hlscan-o.asp

Title: Microsoft Network Connection Manager Could Give a Local User System Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in the Network Connection Manager (NCM) for Windows 2000.  A local user could gain System level privileges.
It is reported that the NCM calls a handler routine whenever a network connection has been established.  The handler routine should run in the security context of the user.  However, it is reported that a flaw allows a local user to cause the handler routine to run in the security context of LocalSystem.  A local user could exploit this condition to specify arbitrary code as the handler and then establish a network connection to cause the code to be executed by the NCM.  The code would run with full system privileges.

Microsoft reports that this vulnerability was discovered as part of a Microsoft security review.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch for Microsoft Windows 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41406

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2 or SP3.  Microsoft plans to include this fix in Windows 2000 SP4.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q326886 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Help and Support Center Hole Lets Remote Users Create URLs That, When Loaded, Will Delete Arbitrary Files on Your System
Impact': A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by a target user, will delete arbitrary files on the target user's computer.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  Microsoft reportedly plans to include a fix in Windows XP SP1.

The author of the report has provided the following potential temporary solutions:

+ delete/move the uplddrvinfo.htm file
+ edit the script of uplddrvinfo.htm to remove the offending code
+ unregister the hcp protocol handler

Title: Windows 2000 Operating System Default Permissions for the System Partition Lets Local Users Bypass Individual File Permissions and Replace Key System Files
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in Windows 2000.  A local user in the 'Everyone' group can replace files in the system partition.
SECURITY.NNOV reported that the Windows 2000 system partition uses weak default permissions.  According to the report, the system partition itself has 'Everyone/Full Control' access permissions by default.  Users with Full Control NTFS permissions for a folder can reportedly delete any file from the folder regardless of the individual file permissions (this is reportedly for POSIX compliance).  

A local user can gain ownership rights and get full control over any system file located in root of system partition.  A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

1. Delete the target file (delete the file rather than placing it in the recycle bin, because additional permissions are required to place files in the recycle bin requires read permission).

2. Create a new file with the same name as the previously deleted file.  The local user is now the owner of this newly created file and has Full Control permission for this file inherited from root folder.

A local user can replace critical system files with trojan files.

Another user has separately reported that this behavior may occur if the Windows installation is upgraded from a previous operating system (e.g., NT).  However, if the system disks on Windows systems are re-formatted during Windows 2000 setup (i.e., clean-installed workstations and servers) the user reports that NTFS permissions will be hardened for the system partition.
Impact': A local user in the 'Everyone' group can replace files in the system partition.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

As a solution, the author of the report indicates that you can replace Full Control permissions for the Everyone group with any reasonable set of permissions for all root folders.

Title: Microsoft Remote Access Service (RAS) Phonebook Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Local System Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Microsoft reported that there is a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Remote Access Service (RAS) for several Microsoft Windows operating systems.  A local user (including a remote user dialing into a terminal server) can execute arbitrary code with Local System privileges.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the RAS phonebook.  The length of certain value is not properly checked, allowing a local user to exploit the buffer overflow.

A local user could modify a phonebook entry using specially crafted, malformed data so that, when the user makes a connection using the modified phonebook entry, arbitrary user-supplied code will be executed.  The local user could also cause the RAS service or the server itself to crash.
Impact':
A local user could cause arbitrary code to be executed with Local System privileges, giving the local user full control over the system.  A local user could also cause the RAS service or the server itself to crash.

Note that, on a Terminal Server, the "local" user could be in a remote location.  However, the user must be authenticated.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches.

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/nts/downloads/security/q318138/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 running RRAS (English Only):

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/nts/downloads/security/q318138/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/terminalserver/downloads/security/q318138/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition running RRAS (English Only):

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/terminalserver/downloads/security/q318138/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/security/q318138/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows XP:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=38833

For Microsoft Windows XP 64-bit Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=39011

Microsoft reports that:

- the Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on systems running SP6a
- the Windows RRAS patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 SP6a (English only)
- the Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition SP6
- the Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition, RRAS patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition SP6
- the Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP1 or SP2, and
- the Windows XP patch can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold.

The vendor plans to include this fix in Windows 2000 SP3 and Windows XP SP1.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q318138 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site at:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US
Underlying OS Comments: Windows NT 4.0, NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition, 2000, XP, and Routing and Remote Access Server (RRAS; aka Steelhead)

Title: Microsoft Windows Help System Buffer Overflows in 'htctrl.ocx' ActiveX Control May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code on a Target User's Computer By Sending Malicious HTML
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Microsoft Windows Help System.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a target user's computer or cause denial of service conditions.  Internet Explorer, Outlook, and Outlook Express users may be affected.
NGSSoftware reported that they have notified Microsoft of several vulnerabilities in the Windows Help System that can be exploited by a remote user sending HTML (via a web page or email) to a target user.  Only minimal information on the vulnerabilities was disclosed at this time.

According to the report, these flaws include stack and heap based buffer overflows.  The report does not confirm that remote code execution is possible but alludes to this.  A remote user can also apparently cause denial of service conditions.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

MGSSoftware reports that Microsoft may have a patch ready for these bugs, but that is not confirmed.

NGSSoftware recommends that users of Internet Explorer and Outlook/Outlook Express rename or delete the Html Help Control Object (htctrl.ocx) and disable active scripting.

Title: Microsoft Windows Debugging Facility for Windows NT4 and 2000 Has Authentication Hole That Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code with SYSTEM Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's debugging facility for Windows NT and Windows 2000.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM level privileges.
Microsoft reports that there is a flaw in the debugging facility's authentication mechanism that allows a local user to gain access to the debugger.  Normally, when a user invokes the debugger to attach to another program, the Windows debugger ensures that the debugger has the appropriate privileges.   However, there is a flaw in how this authentication is performed.  As a result, a local user's unprivileged program could attach to the debugger without having the required privileges.

The local user can exploit the debugger to cause a currently running program to run arbitrary code.  Because many programs run as part of the operating system (with SYSTEM level privileges), the local user can connect to one of these privileged programs and command that program to run arbitrary code as the operating system itself.  This allows the local user to take full control of the system.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with operating system privileges to take full control of the system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix, available at:

For Windows NT 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/nts/downloads/security/q320206/default.asp

For Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition:

http://www.microsoft.com/ntserver/terminalserver/downloads/security/Q320206/default.asp

For Windows 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/security/q320206/default.asp

According to the vendor, the Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on systems running SP6a and the Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0, Terminal Server Edition SP6.  For Windows 2000, the patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP1 or Windows 2000 SP2.

Microsoft reports that the fix will be included in Windows 2000 SP3. 

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q320206 regarding this vulnerability shortly.  It will be available at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Malformed Packets
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator (MSDTC) for Windows 2000.  A remote user can cause the service to crash or to consume resources on the server..
KPMG reported that MSDTC contains a flaw in its processing of malformed packets.  A remote user can reportedly send 20200 null characters to the MSDTC service on TCP port 3372 to cause CPU utilization to reach 100%, the service to refuse additional connections, and kernel resources to be exhausted.
Impact': A remote user can cause the MSDTC service to crash, CPU utilization to reach 100%, and kernel resources to be consumed on the server.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly released a fix as part of MS02-018, a cumulative security patch for Microsoft Internet Information Server, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/ms02-018.asp

However, it is reported that the MS02-018 bulletin does not mention this particular bug fix.

The Microsoft IIS 5.0 patch is available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37824

The IIS 5.0 patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP1 or SP2.

Microsoft plans to include the IIS 5.0 fixes in Windows 2000 SP3.

For information on the patch, see the Microsoft bulletin or refer to our previously issued alert on MS02-018.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 'microsoft-ds' Service Flaw Allows Remote Users to Create Denial of Service Conditions By Sending Malformed Packets
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Windows 2000 under the default LANMAN registry settings.  A remote user could cause CPU usage to reach 100%, denying service on the system.
KPMG reported that a remote user can send malformed packets to the 'microsoft-ds' port (445) on a Windows 2000 host to cause CPU utilization to reach 100%.  This is reportedly possible under the default LANMAN registry settings on Windows 2000 and occurs buecause the LANMAN service will allocate kernel resources to process the malformed packets.

A remote user could send a continuous stream of 10k null characters to TCP port 445 to exploit this vulnerability.
Impact':
A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the server.

Microsoft reports that a remote user can cause memory usage to substantially increase when a server program is subsequently executed, possibly disabling most server functions.  According to the vendor, CPU usage may stay constant at 100% while the server program is running and for a couple of minutes after the server program is terminated.
Solution:
Microsoft has issued the following Knowledge Base article describing two resonlution methods.  The article is titled "Denial of Service Attack on Port 445 May Cause Excessive CPU Use (Q320751)" and is available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q320751

To resolve this issue, use either of the following methods.  Be sure to view the article for some important warnings regarding the use of Registry Editor.

Method 1

Disable NetBIOS over TCP/IP, which also disables port 445:

   1. Click Start , point to Settings , and then click Network and Dial-up Connection .


    # Right-click Local Area Connection , and then click Properties .


    # Click Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) , click Properties , and then click Advanced .


    # Click the WINS tab, click to select the Disable NetBIOS over TCP/IP check box, and then click OK .


IMPORTANT : The preceding configuration may not be supported in an environment where program that require NetBIOS support are being used.

Method 2

Create and then set the MaxWorkItems value in the registry to a value that the computer can support:

   1. Start Registry Editor (Regedt32.exe).


    # Locate the Parameters value under the following key in the registry:


   2. HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\LanmanServer\ On the Edit menu, click Add Value , type MaxWorkItems .


    # Click REG_DWORD , and then click OK .


    # Set the data to the one of the following:


          * 1024 for computers with a large amount of memory (greater than 2 gigabytes of memory).


          * 512 for computers with a medium amount of memory (512 megabytes to -2 gigabytes).


          * 256 for computers with a small amount of memory (less than 512 megabytes).


   3. Quit Registry Editor.
Underlying OS Comments: Windows 2000, 2000 SP1, and 2000 SP2; Server, Advanced Server, Professional

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 Group Policy Object Enforcement Can Be Circumvented if User License Limits are Exceeded
Description:
A potential vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows 2000 Terminal Server.  If the current count of connections to the Group Policy Object (GPO) hosting server exceeds the number of installed user licenses, it is reported that the Group Policy is not applied to any user connecting to the terminal server.
This is reportedly due to connection limits to the SYSVOL SMB share.  The GPO is apparently stored within a directory on the SYSVOL share.  If the number of user licenses is limited or if the administrator has configured manual limits, the access to the GPO on this share may be denied if the number of allowed concurrent connections is exceeded.  In that case, the GPO is not applied to the user's profile.  Any critical restrictions in the GPO are thus bypassed.

An exploit method is described in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user with valid and authorized access to the Terminal Server may be able to login and then access resources that should otherwise be restricted.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided the following workaround recommendations:

* disabling the service "license logging". This keeps the system from contolling connectionlimits
* change licensing from "per server" to "per seat" if this is possible with licensing

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Microsoft Windows NT, 2000, and XP Kernel Buffer Overflow in Processing Multiple UNC Provider (MUP) Requests May Let Local Users Obtain System Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Multiple UNC Provider (MUP) operating system driver.  A local user could obtain Local System access or could cause the server to reboot.
NSFOCUS Security Team reported a vulnerability in Microsoft Windows NT/2000/XP in the MUP code that is implemented by mup.sys in kernel.

When the system receives a UNC file request, MUP saves the request in a buffer of the kernel that has a size of UNC request length + 0x1000 bytes.  Before sending the request to a redirector, MUP copies the request to the buffer again, attaching behind the original request. If the file request is longer than 0x1000 bytes, the buffer overflow can be triggered.  A local user might be able to modify arbitrary kernel memory content by overwriting the adjacent data structure and waiting until the kernel frees the memory.

According to the report, a local user can exploit this bug on Windows 2000.  On Windows NT and XP, exploitation is reportedly possible but more difficult.
Impact': A local user could obtain Local SYSTEM privileges on the system or could cause the system to reboot.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix:

For Windows NT 4.0: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37630

For Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition: 
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37652 

For Windows 2000: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37555 

For Windows XP: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37583 

For Windows XP 64-bit Edition: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37672 

Microsoft reports that the Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on systems running NT SP6a and the Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 TSE SP6. 

The Windows 2000 patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP1 or SP2.

The patch for Windows XP can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold. 

The fix for this issue will be included in Windows 2000 SP3 and in Windows XP SP1.

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Microsoft Windows Operating System File Locking Design May Allow Local Users to Block Group Policy Scripts
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
SECURITY.NNOV reported a file locking denial of service vulnerability with the Microsoft Windows operating system.  It is reported that a local user can lock certain important files to cause security policies and logon scripts to fail to run.
It is reported that a local user can open the Group Policy file with exclusive read access to prevent the Group Policy from being applied.  It is reported that if one Windows application places an exclusive lock on a file, no other application can access the file even if the other application does not want to lock the file. 

According to Microsoft, Group Policy in Windows 2000 is implemented by storing data in the Active Directory and the system volume on the domain controller. This storage location is called the Group Policy Object (GPO). When a host or user logs onto the domain, it reads the GPO and all applicable settings within the GPO.

A local user can prevent Group Policy from being applied for all users affected by the Group Policy Object (GPO).  To exploit this, the local user could login on the domain and open the Group Policy files with 'exclusive read access'.  Then, when any other user login occurs while the Group Policy files are still locked, the GPO settings will not be applied.

According to the vendor, Group Policy application is a transparent process, so a user would not likely be aware that the intended policy settings have not been applied.

Microsoft reports that this vulnerability only applies to Windows 2000 Domain Controllers, as the Group Policy feature was added in Windows 2000.
Impact': A local user can place a lock on a critical file that may block certain group security policy scripts from executing.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Microsoft Windows 2000 Server and Advanced Server: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=36844 

For Microsoft Windows 2000 Datacenter Server: 

Patches for Windows 2000 Datacenter Server are hardware-specific and available from the original equipment manufacturer. 

Microsoft reports that this patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2.  The fix will reportedly be included in Windows 2000 SP3.

Title: Microsoft Windows NT, 2000, and XP Kernel Buffer Overflow in Processing Multiple UNC Provider (MUP) Requests May Let Local Users Obtain System Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Multiple UNC Provider (MUP) operating system driver.  A local user could obtain Local System access or could cause the server to reboot.
NSFOCUS Security Team reported a vulnerability in Microsoft Windows NT/2000/XP in the MUP code that is implemented by mup.sys in kernel.

When the system receives a UNC file request, MUP saves the request in a buffer of the kernel that has a size of UNC request length + 0x1000 bytes.  Before sending the request to a redirector, MUP copies the request to the buffer again, attaching behind the original request. If the file request is longer than 0x1000 bytes, the buffer overflow can be triggered.  A local user might be able to modify arbitrary kernel memory content by overwriting the adjacent data structure and waiting until the kernel frees the memory.

According to the report, a local user can exploit this bug on Windows 2000.  On Windows NT and XP, exploitation is reportedly possible but more difficult.
Impact': A local user could obtain Local SYSTEM privileges on the system or could cause the system to reboot.
Solution:
The vendor reportedly plans to release a fix (MS02-017) shortly:

For the pending vendor bulletin, see: 

http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/MS02-017.asp

Patches are available at:

Microsoft Windows NT 4.0:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37630

Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37652

Microsoft Windows 2000:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37555

Microsoft Windows XP:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37583

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 DCOM Implementation Flaw May Disclose Memory Contents to Remote Users
Description:
BindView reported a security flaw in the Windows 2000 Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) implementation.  A remote user may be able to view memory contents from the vulnerable host.
It is reported that a flaw in Windows 2000's DCOM layer may cause arbitrary parts of a DCOM client's memory to be disclosed onto the network in plaintext form.  The data may include relatively harmless information or potentially sensitive information (such as passwords).  It is reported that the exact impact of this flaw depends on the individual DCOM program.

A DCOM client wishing to use multiple Remote Procedure Call (RPC) interfaces within a single connection will apparently use an 'alter context' request to the server.  According to the report, the DCOM client will send the proper request data followed by a large block of the client's memory space (approximately 1000 bytes in size).

The author describes a demonstration exploit:

"On Windows 2000 SP1, start an empty mmc.exe.  Add in a WMI Control snap-in.  Configure it to connect to another computer, and use the 'Log on as' dialog to specify credentials.  Then get the properties from the remote machine.  This lead, in our case, to the supplied password being leaked onto the network in plaintext.  This didn't occur every time, but happened on several different occasions."
Impact': A Windows 2000 DCOM client may disclose memory contents onto the network.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix (Windows 2000 SRP1).  For more information, see the Microsoft Knowledge Base article:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;q300367

Title: Windows NT and 2000 Session Manager Debug Hole Lets Local Users Obtain Handles to Any Process or Thread to Obtain Elevated Privileges on the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Windows Session Manager on Windows NT and Windows 2000.  A local user can obtain handles to any process or thread and can obtain administrator privileges on the system.
It is reported that the Windows Session Manager (smss.exe) contains a feature that allows a local user with 'Everyone' user privileges to get a handle to any process or thread.  If the target process is running with LocalSystem or Administrator privileges, the handle will apparently have enough access to promote the user to System or Administrator levels.

A local user can reportedly request that the debugging subsystem within the Session Manager create (or duplicate) one or more handle to the target process using the following steps:

1. Become dbgss client using the bgUiConnectToDbg API.

2. Connect to DbgSsApiPort LPC port (ZwConnectPort).  Everyone has access to this port, according to the report.

3. Ask dbgss to handle CreateProcess SsApi with client id (or pid or tid only) of target (ZwRequestPort).

4. Wait for dbgss to reply with CREATE_PROCESS_DEBUG_EVENT (WaitForDebugEvent). Message contains duplicated handle(s).

5. When debugger's thread terminates (e.g. on logoff), the target process or thread is terminated (as if it was regularly debugged).

For the exploit code and a fix provided by the author, see:

http://www.anticracking.sk/EliCZ/bugs/DebPloit.zip

It is reported that Windows XP is not affected.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the system
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided the following HotFix information:

0) Disasm %systemroot%\system32\smss.exe file:
   dumpbin smss.exe -disasm > before.txt   
1) Edit %systemroot%\system32\smss.exe file.
2) Find offset of ansi string "\DbgSsApiPort".
3) Find reference to (find the offset) this string in code.
4) "Below" this reference but "above" call to NtCreatePort is filled OBJECT_ATTRIBUTES structure.
5) Put NULL to OBJECT_ATTRIBUTES.SecurityDescriptor by using the register that contains 0 (and with which are initialized other fields: RootDirectory, Attributes and SecurityQualityOfService. This is one-byte change.
6) Correct PE checksum - optional.
7) After rebooting only system and administrators can connect to \DbgSsApiPort LPC port.

For additional information on the fix provided by the author, see:

http://www.anticracking.sk/EliCZ/bugs/DebPloit.zip

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 Automatic Log Off Policy Fails to Expire Sessions in Progress
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows 2000 automatic log off policy.  A valid and authenticated user may not be automatically logged off when a time-based log off policy specifies the log off to occur.
It is reported that the "Automatically log off users when logon time expires" feature does not work properly in some situations. If a time-based policy is configured to deny logon during a certain time period and a user is logged in prior to the time period, the user account will not be denied access during the time period.

The specific test method used is described in the Source Message.
Impact': A valid and authenticated user may not be automatically logged off when a time-based log off policy specifies that user logons should be denied.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows Operating System Shell URL Handler Bug Lets Remote Users Create HTML That Could Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed on Another User's System in Certain Situations
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Windows operating system shell (Windows Desktop).  A remote user could create HTML code to exploit the vulnerability on another user's system under certain very specific situations, causing arbitrary code to be executed on the target (victim) user's host.
An unchecked buffer reportedly exists in the Windows Shell (Windows Desktop) in one of the functions that helps to locate incompletely removed applications on the system.  A local user could reportedly trigger the buffer overflow and cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the local user.  By itself, this may not represent a risk.  However, Microsoft indicates that under 'very unusual conditions', this vulnerability could be exploited via a web page.

If the local user has installed and then uninstalled an application with custom URL handlers and if the application's uninstall routine failed to correctly remove the application completely, an exploit may be possible.  When an application is installed, the Windows Shell allows the application to register a new URL type as a custom URL handler to allow a specific URL to cause the application to execute.  For example, Outlook 20002 registers "outlook://" as a custom URL handler.  If the uninstall routine does not remove a URL handler, the exploit may be possible.  A remote user could create an HTML web page or HTML-based e-mail message that could exploit the 'orphaned' URL handler and overrun the buffer.

The buffer overflow reportedly exists in a part of the Windows Shell that helps to locate programs when they have been incompletely removed. The affected function is apparently invoked only when the Shell can locate a custom URL handler but not its associated application.
Impact': If certain conditions are satisfied (these are listed in the 'Description' section and are described by Microsoft as 'very unusual'), a remote user could create an HTML web page or HTML-based e-mail message that, if loaded by a target user, could cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system in the target user's security context.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Windows 98:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37015 

For Windows NT 4.0:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=36867

For Windows NT 4.0 with Active Desktop:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=37015 

For Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=36869 

For Windows NT 2000:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=36880 

The Windows 98 patch can be installed on system running Windows 98 and Windows 98SE. 

The Windows NT 4.0 patch can be installed on systems running Service Pack 6a. 

The Windows NT 4.0 Terminal Server Edition patch can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 TSE Service Pack 6. 

The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 Service Pack 2. 

Microsoft reports that the fix for this issue will be included in Windows 2000 SP3.

Title: Microsoft Windows SMTP Service Lets Remote Users Send or Relay Unauthorized Mail (including SPAM) Via the Server
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS02-11) warning of a vulnerability in the Windows SMTP service. A remote user could relay unauthorized mail via the system.
It is reported that the Windows 2000 and Windows NT 4.0 SMTP service contains a vulnerability in the processing of valid responses from the NTLM authentication layer of the underlying operating system.

The Windows SMTP service, upon receiving notification from the NTLM authentication layer that a user has been authenticated, reportedly fail to perform the required additional checks before granting the user access to the service. In most cases, a remote user that can successfully authenticate to the server can gain access to the SMTP service.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a maximum severity rating of "Low".
Impact': A remote user that can successfully authenticate to the server can gain access to the SMTP service and, for example, send or relay mail via the server.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  In April 2004, the vendor noted that Windows NT 4.0 is also affected and added a fix for Windows NT 4.0.

Windows 2000 Server, Professional and Advanced Server:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID= 36556

Windows NT Server 4.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=457C0C18-8C3E-4923-B395-614C117F13C5&displaylang=en

Windows 2000 Datacenter Server:

Patches for Windows 2000 Datacenter Server are hardware-specific and available from the original equipment manufacturer, the vendor said.

The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on Windows 2000 SP1 and the Windows NT Server 4.0 patch can be installed on Windows NT Server 4.0 SP6a.

This fix will be included in Windows 2000 SP3.

A reboot is required after installing this patch.

Title: Microsoft XML Core Services in Microsoft Windows XP Operating System Lets Remote Scripts Access and Send Local Files
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft issued Security Bulletin MS02-008 confirming a previously reported vulnerability in the Microsoft XML Core Services that affects Microsoft Windows XP.  A remote user may be able to access files and content on another user's computer.
Microsoft XML Core Services (MSXML) includes the XMLHTTP ActiveX control. A flaw reportedly exists in how the XMLHTTP control applies Internet Explorer (IE) security zone settings to a redirected data stream returned in response to a request for data from a web site. A remote user could specify a data source that is on the user s local system and then use this to return information from the local system to the attacker's web site. 

Microsoft reports that affected versions of MSXML ship as part of several products. The patch mentioned in their advisory should reportedly be applied if any of the following Microsoft products are being used: 

  Microsoft Windows XP 
  Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 
  Microsoft SQL Server 2000 

MSXML can apparentely be installed separately as a DLL in the system32 subdirectory. Users that have any of the following files in that directory should install the patch:

  MSXML2.DLL 
  MSXML3.DLL 
  MSXML4.DLL 

The vendor notes that MSXML.DLL is not affected (as it is an earlier version).

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a "Moderate" risk rating for Internet and Intranet Servers and a "Critical" risk rating for Client Systems. 

This affects Microsoft XML Core Services 2.6, 3.0, and 4.0, which also includes Microsoft Windows XP, SQL Server 2000, and Internet Explorer 6.0. 

[Editor's note:  This flaw was reported on our site in December 2001 as a bug in the Microsoft XMLHTTP component shipped with Internet Explorer 6.  However, Microsoft has confirmed that the bug also affects products other than IE.]
Impact': A remote user can create a script in an HTML web page or e-mail message that, when loaded and executed by the target (victim) user's browser, will access and send known files on the target user's computer.  The script may also be able to access web site content from a web site that the target user has recently visited, including content that the target user submitted to the web site.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for Microsoft XML Core Services (installed as part of IE):

  http://www.microsoft.com/Windowsupdate 

This can be installed on MSXML versions 2.6 Gold, 3.0 Gold, 3.0 Service Pack 1, 3.0 Service Pack 2, or 4.0 Gold

This fix will reportedly be included in the following future service packs:

  MSXML, 3.0 SP3 and 4.0 Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft Windows 2000 Service Pack 3 
  Microsoft Windows XP Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Service Pack 3 

Microsoft plans to release Knowledge Base article Q317244 regarding this flaw.

Title: Microsoft Windows Terminal Services May Cause the System's Screen Saver Lockout Mechanism to Fail in Certain Situations
Version(s): Windows 2000 Server with SP0, SP1 and SP2, and the Terminal Server client under Win98SE, Windows 2000 Pro and Windows XP Pro
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Windows Terminal Services.  In certain situations, a Windows Terminal Services client may cause the Windows screen saver lockout mechanism to fail to lock out the system.
It is reported that if a user applies the "disconnect" feature of the Terminal Services client, the user's system will fail to lockout the system if left idle.

The following steps can reportedly be used to trigger the flaw:

'Connect to a server running Terminal Services in Administration mode.  Leave the connection open and idle long enough for the "screen saver" to activate. Disconnect the session by closing the window.  Reconnect to the session, and the "screen saver" will never activate.'
Impact': If an administrator applies the "disconnect" feature of the Terminal Services client and then leaves the workstation idle, a physically local user may be able to access the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor has reportedly acknowledge the bug and indicated that it should be fixed.

Title: Windows XP Networking Port May Allow Remote Users to Deny Service By Sending a Stream of TCP SYN Packets
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Windows XP.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the server.
A remote user can reportedly send a specially crafted packet with the TCP SYN flag set to the Windows XP networking port 445 to cause the server to consume all available CPU resources.  It is reported that this was tested with 3000 packets sent at an upload speed of 20K [presumably 20 KBytes per second].  This apparently caused the server to consume all CPU resources within 20 seconds after the initiation of the stream, preventing other tasks from functioning until the packet stream concluded.

It is reported that this port is enabled by default.
Impact': A remote user can cause a denial of service condition.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 and Windows 2000 Domain Controllers May Give Elevated Privileges to Remote Users Who Are Valid Administrators on Other Trusted Domains
Version(s): Windows NT 4.0, Windows 2000
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in their Windows NT and Windows 2000 Domain Controller software.  A remote user with administrative privileges on a domain controller can gain elevated privileges on another domain that trusts the user's domain controller.
Microsoft reports that the domain controller software fails to validate all Security Identifiers (SIDs) supplied by a remote trusted domain.  A user who is a valid administrator on a trusted domain can reportedly insert SIDs of his choice into the domain controller's authorization data to obtain the privileges associated with a user in another domain that trusts his domain.

As reported by Microsoft, when a user in a trusted domain requests access to a resource in a different trusting domain (where the "trusting" domain trusts the "trusted" domain), the trusted domain will supply a list of SIDs that represent authorization data regarding the the user's identity and group memberships.  This information is used by the trusting domain to determine whether to grant the user's request for resource access.

It is reported that the trusting domain does not verify that the trusted domain is a valid authority for all of the SIDs listed in the authorization data.  So, a user who is an administrator on a trusted domain can add a SID to his domain controller for a user or security group not in that domain, and the trusting domain will accept the data as valid.

Microsoft notes that this is a difficult exploit that requires technical knowledge to create and install operating system level code to inject the SIDs -- there is apparently no easy mechanism for an administrator to inject false SIDs.
Impact':
A remote user with valid administrative privileges on one domain controller can gain elevated privileges on a different domain that trusts the user's domain controller.  These privileges can reportedly be associated with any user or group, including the Domain Administrators group for the trusting domain.

Microsoft has assessed the impact as a "moderate" risk for Intranet servers and a "low" risk for Internet servers.
Solution:
Microsoft has issued a patch.  However, there are some apparently significant considerations to be made before installing the patch and making the appropriate configuration.  See the caveats and descriptions provided by Microsoft in their full advisory, available at the Vendor URL.

For Windows NT 4.0 Server and Windows NT 4.0 Server, Enterprise Edition, the patch is included in the Windows NT 4.0 Security Roll-up Package, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/release.asp?ReleaseID=31240

For Windows 2000 Server and Advanced Server, this patch is included in Windows 2000 Security Roll-up Package 1, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/critical/q311401/default.asp

For Microsoft Windows 2000 Datacenter Server, the patches are reportedly hardware-specific and available from the original equipment manufacturer. 

Microsoft reports that the Windows NT 4.0 Security Roll-up Package can be installed on systems running SP6a and that the Windows 2000 Security Roll-up Package 1 can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 SP2.

The vendor reports that the fix for Windows 2000 will be part of the future Windows 2000 SP3 release.

This patch supercedes several earlier patches.  For the full list, see the Vendor URL.

Microsoft has issued warnings regarding the mechanism designed to fix this vulnerability.  Please read the vendor's advisory carefully.  In summary, "SID Filtering" can be installed on a "trusting" domain controller and configured for a specific trusted domain.  When this occurs, the trusting domain will apparently check all incoming SIDs from the specified trusted domain and will remove any SIDs that don t belong to the trusted domain.  Note that SID Filtering is *not* enabled by default with the patch.

For details on enabling and configuring SID Filtering (using a registry entry), see Microsoft Knowledge Base article Q289243.

It is reported that SID Filtering may screen out legitimate SIDs in certain cases (described in the vendor advisory), so this option should be carefully considered in advance of implementation.

Title: Windows 2000 TCP Stack Bug Lets Remote Users Cause All Memory to Be Consumed on the Server
Description:
Security.NNOV reported a denial of service vulnerability in Microsoft Windows 2000.  A remote user can cause the server to consume all available memory.
It is reported that there is a memory leak in the TCP stack in Windows 2000.  A remote user can send certain TCP packets, such as empty TCP packets with the ACK and FIN flags set, to cause memory to leak from non-paged kernel space.

A demonstration exploit is available (see the Base64-encoded attachment in the Source Message).
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to consume all available memory and crash.
Solution:
The vendor released a solution last year.  The solution is available in Windows 2000 SP2.  Apply Service Pack 2 (SP2), available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/servicepacks/sp2/

Title: Microsoft Windows NT/2000 Authentication Lockout Bug May Record Successful Logins as Failed Login Attempts in Certain Situations
Description:
An authentication logging vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Windows NT and 2000 operating systems.  In certain situations, a local user's successful login may be logged as a failed login attempt in the security log.
It is reported that, under certain conditions, a local user's successful login will be recorded as a failed login (security event 539) instead of a successful login (security event 528).

The following conditions must be met.  The system must be configured to lockout an account after an incorrect password has been entered a certain number of times.  The system must be locked at the time of the attack due to an incorrect password having been entered too many times.  The system must be configured to allow a host to be unlocked even when the account is locked out (this is apparently the default configuration).  The attacker must know the password or be able to rapidly guess it.

For additional information, see the original report at:

http://www.heysoft.de/nt/lbh.htm
Impact': A local user who knows the password can reportedly login on a locked host and then relock the host again without leaving a trace of the successful login in the security log.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor has apparently confirmed this and may be working on a fix.

The author of the report describes the following workaround:

"Apply the fix suggested in KB article Q188700 (http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;q188700). This fix requires you to add the following Registry value: 
 Key:
          HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon
 Value:
          ForceUnlockLogon
 Type:
          DWORD
 Content:
          1 (on) or 0 (off)"

Apparently, when ForceUnlockLogon is set to 1, a locked account can not unlock a locked machine, which reportedly prevents this exploit.

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Manifest Processing Bug Lets Local Users Corrupt the System and Cause the Boot Process to Fail
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Windows XP operating system.  A local user can corrupt the system.
A local user can reportedly cause the operating system to fail to complete the boot process by giving the explorer.exe file invalid skinning information (*.manifest-file).  It is reported that the XML code in the skinning file is not verified by the operating system.  If the manifest file contains invalid code, the application apparently won't start.  If the manifest for explorer.exe is corrupt, the system reportedly will not boot.

It is reported that the Windows XP repair function will not correct the error.

For more information, see the article posted to german supernatural-forum (German language article):

http://www.supernature-forum.de/vbb/printthread.php?threadid=6458
Impact': A local user can cause the boot process to fail.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests using a tool to verify the *.manifests before shutdown.

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Upgrade Effectively Removes Patches from Internet Explorer (IE) During Upgrade, Leaving Users Exposed to IE Vulnerabilities
Version(s): Tested on Windows XP Professional Upgrade Version 2002; Affected Internet Explorer Version 6.0.2600.0000 Update Patches:; Q313675;
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Windows XP Pro upgrade package.  The upgrade process will roll back Microsoft Internet Explorer (IE) 6.0 files, effectively removing all patches that may have been applied on the user's PC.
It is reported that the upgrade process installs a new, un-patched version of IE 6.0.

It is also reported that the auto-detect on-line upgrade feature does not detect this un-patched version of IE and will fail to recommend a critical fix described in:

http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/ms01-058.asp
Impact': The upgrade process may remove patches that have been applied to Internet Explorer 6.0 (earlier versions were not tested).  This may leave the user exposed to vulnerabilities in un-patched versions of IE.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests manually applying the necessary patches to IE after upgrading to XP.
Underlying OS Comments: Tested while upgrading Windows 98SE to Windows XP Pro

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Task Manager Will Not Kill Certain Processes
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Windows XP Task Manager.  The Task Manager will not delete certain process names.
It is reported that the Windows XP Task Manager has some security mechanisms that disallow the termination of certain critical system executables:

lsass.exe
services.exe
winlogon.exe
smss.exe

A user can rename any executable (such as trojan code) to one of those names to keep an administrator from killing the executable via Task Manager.  This apparently occurs even though the renamed service executable is running under the username of the person currently logged on, and not SYSTEM.
Impact': A local user can rename an executable file and launch it such that the process cannot be killed via Task Manager.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Remote Desktop Client May Disclose Recently Used Account Names to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Windows XP Remote Desktop client.  A remote user sniffing the network can obtain user account names sent by the Remote Desktop client.
It is reported that the Remote Desktop client remembers the account name that was most recently used to establish a remote desktop session with another host and apparently transmits that name when attempting to establish a subsequent session.

The author of the report notes that this vulnerability was first detected by Szymon Nowak.
Impact': A remote user can sniff the network to determine user account names.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: Tested on Windows XP Professional in a workgroup environment

Title: Microsoft C Runtime Format String Flaw Lets Remote Users Crash the Microsoft SQL Server Service
Version(s): Can be triggered via Microsoft SQL Server 7.0, Microsoft SQL Server 2000
Description:
Microsoft reported a denial of service vulnerability in the C runtime code that ships with Windows NT, 2000, and XP.  The format string vulnerabilities can be triggered via Microsoft SQL Server, causing the SQL Server service to crash.
There is reportedly a format string vulnerability in the C runtime functions that Microsoft's SQL Server calls when installed on Windows NT  4.0, Windows  2000 or Windows XP. 

Microsoft notes that this format string flaw will not allow for the execution of arbitrary code.  Apparently, the C runtime code would always be overrun with the same values regardless of the user-supplied input.  Because of this, the impact is reportedly limited to a denial of service.

A remote user could load and execute a database query that calls one of the affected functions.  Or, if a web site or other database front-end accepts and processes arbitrary queries, a remote user could supply a URL that will cause the query to call an affected function.
Impact': A remote user could cause a SQL Server service to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch, but recommends that administrators apply the C runtime patch only to systems judged to be at high risk. Microsoft recommends that customers carefully weigh whether they need to apply the C runtime patch for two reasons: 

"1) The C runtime vulnerability only allows denial of service attacks, so the threat it poses is somewhat lower.  

2) The C runtime plays a crucial role in the operating system itself.  While we are confident that both patches are well-tested, if there were a regression error in the C runtime, the effects would likely be serious and widespread."

The C runtime patch is available at the following locations:

Windows NT 4.0 and Windows 2000:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=33500 

Windows XP:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=35023 

The patch for the Windows NT 4.0 C runtime can be installed on systems running Windows NT 4.0 Service Pack 6a.  The patch for the Windows NT 2000 C runtime can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 Service Pack 1 or Service Pack 2. The patch for the Windows XP C runtime can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold. 

Microsoft reports that the fix for this issue will be included in Windows 2000 Service Pack 3 and Windows XP Service Pack 1.

Title: Microsoft Windows Universal Plug and Play Component Buffer Overflow Gives Remote Users System Level Access to Windows XP and 98/ME Hosts
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
eEye Digital Security reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in a component of Microsoft's Windows XP, 98, and ME operating systems.  A remote user could execute arbitrary code with System level privileges to gain control of the system.
A remote user can send malformed Universal Plug and Play (UPnP) NOTIFY advertisements at various speeds to trigger a buffer overflow on the target server.

It is reported that Windows XP ships by default with a vulnerable UPnP service that contains a buffer overflow.  It is reported that Windows ME does not ship by default with the UPnP service, however some OEM versions do provide the UPNP service by default.  Furthermore, it is reportedly possible to install the Windows XP Internet Connection Sharing on top of Windows 98, making that operating system vulnerable.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

NOTIFY * HTTP/1.1
HOST: 239.255.255.250:1900
CACHE-CONTROL: max-age=10
LOCATION: http://IPADDRESS:PORT/<buffer>.xml
NT: urn:schemas-upnp-org:device:InternetGatewayDevice:1
NTS: ssdp:alive
SERVER: EEYE/2001 UPnP/1.0 product/1.1
USN: uuid:EEYE

eEye reports that there are multiple points of exploitation.  Furthermore, because the Simple Service Discovery Protocol (SSDP) service listens on Multicast and Broadcast addresses, a remote user can apparently gain System level access to an entire network of XP machines with only one anonymous UDP SSDP attack session.

Additonal details of the vulnerability are provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can gain System level access on the server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix:

Microsoft Windows 98/98SE:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=34991 

Microsoft Windows ME:

http://download.microsoft.com/download/winme/Update/22940/WinMe/EN-US/314757USAM.EXE 

Microsoft Windows XP: 

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=34951 

The vendor reports that the patch for Windows 98 and 98SE can be installed on any Windows 98 or 98SE system on which the Windows XP Internet Connection Sharing client has been installed. 

The patch for Windows ME can be installed on systems running Windows ME Gold. 

The patch for Windows XP can be installed on systems running Windows XP Gold. 

The vendor plans to include the fix for this issue in Windows XP Service Pack 1.

This patch supersedes patch MS01-054.

For instruction on how to verify the patch installation, see the Vendor URL.
Underlying OS Comments: Windows XP (All default systems); Windows 98, 98SE, and ME (Certain configurations)

Title: Microsoft Windows XP Hot Key Function Lets Physically Local Users Execute Administrator Hot Key Functions in Certain Situations
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Windows XP operating system.  A physically local user can use hot keys to cause the assigned programs of another user to launch.
When a user's host input devices are inactive for a certain period, Windows XP will require the physically local user to reauthenticate before providing access.  However, if the user has assigned functions to the 'hot keys' then those hot keys may remain accessible and may not require reauthentication.  As a result, if an administrative user has left his host unattended but XP has locked the input devices, a physically local user can activate the administrative user's hot keys without needing to authenticate.
Impact': A physically local user may be able to activate hot keys that are associated with an administrator's account and launch administrative programs without authentication.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.  As a workaround, uses can disable the hot key function.

Title: Microsoft Windows Explorer Discloses Stored FTP Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A password disclosure vulnerability was reported in Windows Explorer, part of Microsoft's Windows operating system.  A local user can view a saved FTP username and password stored under 'My Network Places.'
It is reported that when a "Network Place" has been added to "My Network Places" with a saved username and password, it is possible for a local user to cause Explorer to display the password in cleartext format by altering the path in the address bar.

The following steps will apparently trigger the vulnerability: 

- Double click on My Network Places.
- Double Click on Add Network Place
- Provide the internet address of ftp://[hostname]
- Provide, when prompted, the username of someuser by deselecting anonymous login.  Windows will inform you that you will be prompted for a password.
- Select "open this network place when I click Finish"
- When prompted, provide your password.  Click the checkbox that says "remember my password".

At this point, the local user is logged in and the address bar should display:

    ftp://someuser@[hostname]/

If the local user then clicks on the address bar and adds the string '../' to the end of the URL, the address bar will then display:

    ftp://someuser@[hostname]/../

If the local user then clicks on the address bar yet again and adds the string '../' to the end of the URL, the password will be displayed:

    ftp://someuser:somepass@[hostname]/usr/home/someuser/../../

It is reported that this occurs regardless of whether the user selects to have Windows remember the password or not.
Impact': A local user can view the FTP username and password of a user logged into to an FTP session with Windows Explorer
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: tested on Windows XP Professional (v5.1.2600), Windows 2000, and Windows 98

Title: (Vendor Cannot Reproduce Claim) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Utility May Disclose Sensitive Information to Local Users
Description:
Team RADIX reported an information disclosure vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs application.  A local user may be able to obtain information from a previous user's session.
It is reported that the command line utility "RunAs" (which uses the RunAs service) fails to erase a buffer after the application terminates.  Credentials supplied by the user are not destroyed and apparently linger on the utility's stack after the utility terminates.  As a result, a local user could access the information when the memory page is reallocated.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user may be able to access information from a previous user via the RunAs application buffer.
Solution:
The vendor has been unable to reproduce the claim that one user can obtain the credentials of another user.  The vendor reports that the only case in which they were able to recover the credentials of another user was one in which the local attacker already had administrative privileges on the machine and used a debugger to directly access memory.

The vendor also reports having asked the original author of the vulnerability report for information or exploit code but receiving none.

Title: (The Vendor Questions The Risk Due to this Vulnerability) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Service May Disclose Authentication Credentials to Local Users
Description:
Team RADIX reported another vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs service.  A local user could obtain the authentication credentials of another user and masquerade as the other user to gain escalated privileges on the server.
It is reported that the Windows 2000 CreateProcessWithLogonW API, which uses the RunAs service to start applications, does not perform server-side authenticity validation prior to sending a user's credentials to the application.  Apparently, if the Windows 2000 RunAs service is ever in a stopped state, a local user can access the service's named pipe communication channel "\\.\pipe\secondarylogon" to recover the RunAs service user's plaintext authentication credentials and can then masquerade as that user to other RunAs applications.  This could reportedly lead to privilege escalation on the server.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user could obtain the authentication credentials of another user and could use that to gain escalated privileges on the server.
Solution: The vendor notes that for a local user to exploit this vulnerability, the local user must already have administrative privileges in order to pause the RunAs service.  The implication is that if a user already has administrative privileges on the server, then the exploit is not necessary.

Title: (Vendor Confirms) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Service Allows Local Users to Disable the Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Team RADIX reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Windows 2000 RunAs service.  A local user can effectively disable the functionality of RunAs services.
It is reported that one client can connect to the named pipe "\\.\pipe\secondarylogon" that is used by the RunAs service and never request any service, effectively blocking out any other requests until the client disconnects or sends data.  If more than one client requests service from the RunAs service, the clients will receive the error "231: All pipe instances are busy."

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can effectively block the RunAs service.  The vendor reports that this would allow a local user to block his own RunAs service or, on a terminal server, would allow a local user to block the RunAs service for other users on that server.
Solution: The vendor has confirmed the vulnerability.  The vendor reports that the changes to fix this vulnerability are complex and are planned for Windows 2000 Service Pack 3 (which is apparently scheduled for February 2002).

Title: Microsoft Windows Operating System File Locking Design May Allow Local Users to Block Group Policy Scripts
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
SECURITY.NNOV reported a file locking denial of service vulnerability with the Microsoft Windows operating system.  It is reported that a local user can lock certain important files to cause security policies and logon scripts to fail to run.
It is reported that if one Windows application places an exclusive lock on a file, no other application can access the file even if the other application does not want to lock the file.  This is apparently in contrast to how other operating systems work (which is to only deny access to a locked file when another application attempts to lock the file).

It is reportedly possible for a local unprivileged user to stop security policies and logon scripts from running by locking policy files on domain controllers, to lock a screensaver file to prevent other users from locking the workstation, to deny an administrator access to administrative utilities and/or batch jobs, to deny user logons, and to deny access to shared programs and documents.
Impact': A local user can place a lock on a critical file that may block certain group security policy scripts from executing.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  Microsoft has reportedly confirmed some form of the issue and is proposing an audit notification solution.  See the Source Message for more information.

Title: Terminal Services on Microsoft Windows 2000 and XP Allow Remote Users to Log Bogus IP Addresses Instead of the User's Genuine Address
Description:
Xato Security reported a vulnerability in the Terminal Services on Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows XP.  A remote user can cause an alternate IP address to be logged by the Terminal Services Manager and the Event log instead of the user's genuine IP address.
It is reported that the Terminal Services Manager MMC utility and the Event Log can be used to view the status of Terminal Services connections.  The status details provided include the 'Client Address.'  This field is apparently based on information provided by the originating client via the Remote Desktop Protocol, rather than based on information determined from the operating system TCP/IP stack.  As a result, a remote user can initiate a connection via a NAT-enabled router that will appear (in these log files) to originate from a different IP address rather than from the IP address used by the NAT router.

It is reported that the operating system itself is not tricked by the bogus IP address.
Impact': A remote user can attempt terminal services connections that may appear in certain logs to have originated from a bogus IP address.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests some alternative workarounds, described in the Source Message.
Underlying OS Comments: Windows 2000 (all SP levels) and Windows XP are affected; Windows NT4 TS Edition was not tested

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Service May Disclose Authentication Credentials to Local Users
Description:
Team RADIX reported another vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs service.  A local user could obtain the authentication credentials of another user and masquerade as the other user to gain escalated privileges on the server.
It is reported that the Windows 2000 CreateProcessWithLogonW API, which uses the RunAs service to start applications, does not perform server-side authenticity validation prior to sending a user's credentials to the application.  Apparently, if the Windows 2000 RunAs service is ever in a stopped state, a local user can access the service's named pipe communication channel "\\.\pipe\secondarylogon" to recover the RunAs service user's plaintext authentication credentials and can then masquerade as that user to other RunAs applications.  This could reportedly lead to privilege escalation on the server.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user could obtain the authentication credentials of another user and could use that to gain escalated privileges on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  It is reported that the vendor plans to issue a fix within service pack 3 (SP3), apparently scheduled for release in February 2002.  The author of the report recommends not using the RunAs service until a fix is available.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Utility May Disclose Sensitive Information to Local Users

It is reported that the command line utility "RunAs" (which uses the RunAs service) fails to erase a buffer after the application terminates.  Credentials supplied by the user are not destroyed and apparently linger on the utility's stack after the utility terminates.  As a result, a local user could access the information when the memory page is reallocated.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user may be able to access information from a previous user via the RunAs application buffer.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  It is reported that the vendor plans to include the fix within service pack 3 (SP3), apparently scheduled for February 2002.  The author of the report recommends not using the RunAs service until a fix is available.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 RunAs Service Allows Local Users to Disable the Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Team RADIX reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Windows 2000 RunAs service.  A local user can effectively disable the functionality of RunAs services.
It is reported that one client can connect to the named pipe "\\.\pipe\secondarylogon" that is used by the RunAs service and never request any service, effectively blocking out any other requests until the client disconnects or sends data.  If more than one client requests service from the RunAs service, the clients will receive the error "231: All pipe instances are busy."

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
