Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  It is reported that the vendor will include a fix within service pack 3 (SP3), apparently scheduled for February 2002.  The author of the report recommends not using the RunAs service until a fix is available.

Title: Macintosh Cients Using Windows 2000 NTFS Volumes May Modify Directory Permissions in Certain Cases
Version(s): Windows 2000 server SP1 with a Mac client using OS 9.x and UAM version 5.
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Macintosh clients using NTFS volumes on a Windows 2000 server.  The Mac clients will modify permissions in certain cases.
It is reported that Macintosh clients automatically modify inherited NTFS permissions when creating subdirectory within a volume.


It is reported that this bug has been reproduced by Microsoft.

An description of the issue is provided below:

Data - root folder
1.      shared as data
2.      share permissions = Everyone (change)
3.      NTFS permissions = Administrators (full), Everyone (list)

External - subdirectory
1.      NTFS permissions = Administrators (full), Everyone (list)
2.      Allow inheritable permissions is checked.

XYZ - subdirectory (team folder)
1.      NTFS permissions = Administrators (full), Everyone (list), XYZ
Global Group (modify)
2.      Allow inheritable permissions is checked.

Comps_for_site_dev - subdirectory
1.      NTFS permissions = Adminstrators (full), Everyone (list), XYZ Global
Group (modify)
2.      Allow inheritable permissions is checked.

Global_elements - subdirectory
1.      This is the directory created by the Macintosh.
2.      NTFS permissions = Administrators (full), Domain Users (read & execute), Everyone (read & execute), XYZ Global Group (modify), SYSTEM (modify), MacintoshUsername (full)
3.      Allow inheritable permissions is checked.
4.      None of the above permissions were assigned in addition to the ones in comps_for_site_dev. All additional users, groups, and permissions were automatically granted and/or modified when the Mac user created the folder.
Impact': A remote user with a Mac client creating a subdirectory on a Windows 2000 NTFS volume may modify the inherited permissions.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Terminal Servers Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Certain Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) Packets
Version(s): Windows NT 4.0 Server, Terminal Server Edition; Windows 2000 Server, Advanced Server, and Datacenter Server
Description:
Microsoft issued an advisory warning of a vulnerability in their Terminal Services for Windows NT and Windows 2000.  A remote user can cause the server to crash.
Microsoft reports that the implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) in the terminal service in Windows NT  4.0 and Windows 2000 contains a flaw.  A remote user can send a particular series of RDP data packets to cause the server to crash.  A reboot is required to return to normal operations.
Impact': A remote user can send a specific series of RDP packets to cause the server to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches.  For the patch locations, see the Vendor URL.

The Windows NT 4.0 patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Windows NT Server 4.0, Terminal Server Edition, Service Pack 6.  The Windows 2000 patch can be installed on systems running Service Pack 1 or Service Pack 2. 

The fix for this issue will reportedly be included in Windows 2000 Service Pack 3. 
Note that the Windows 2000 patch supersedes the one provided in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS01-006.

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Windows 2000 IrDA Infrared Device Driver Lets Infrared Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in Windows 2000.  A buffer overflow in the IrDA infrared device driver lets remote users crash the system via the infrared port.
If a physically local user sends an IrDA test frame to the host's infrared port, the host will reportedly crash and then reboot. IrDA test frames can apparently be generated by the irdaping utility under GNU/Linux.

It is reported that remote code execution cannot be achieved via this vulnerability.
Impact': A physically local user within IrDA transmission distance can cause the host to crash and then reboot.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix:            http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/critical/q252795/default.asp

The vendor reports that this patch can be installed on systems running Windows 2000 Service Pack 1 or Windows 2000 Service Pack 2.  The vendor plans to include the fix for this issue in Windows 2000 Service Pack 3. 

The following registry key confirms that the patch has been applied:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Updates\Windows 2000\SP3\Q252795. 

The date/time and version information in the following registry key can be used to confirm the individual files:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Updates\Windows 2000\SP3\Q252795\Filelist

See the Vendor URL for the latest patch information.

Title: Windows 2000 IrDA Infrared Device Driver Lets Infrared Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in Windows 2000.  A buffer overflow in the IrDA infrared device driver lets remote users crash the system via the infrared port.
If a physically local user sends an IrDA test frame to the host's infrared port, the host will reportedly crash and then reboot. IrDA test frames can apparently be generated by the irdaping utility under GNU/Linux.

It is reported that remote code execution cannot be achieved via this vulnerability.
Impact': A physically local user within IrDA transmission distance can cause the host to crash and then reboot.
Solution:
The vendor is preparing a patch for release.  See the Vendor URL for patch information, or check the Message History of this alert.

A workaround is to disable the IrDA device under the Device Manager.  It is reported that disabling communication via the IrDA software does not prevent the vulnerability.

Title: Microsoft Windows TCP/IP Stack Vulnerable to a Certain Man-in-the-Middle Denial of Service Attack
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Microsoft Windows TCP/IP stack that allows a man-in-the-middle to cause a denial of service condition.
It is reported that a man-in-the-middle attack that consists of just two TCP packets can cause a significant increase in network traffic and can cause the TCP connection to hang.

A remote user that can monitor network activity and collect the sequence and ACK numbers of an active TCP connection can then trigger an ACK loop by sending a spoofed TCP packet with the ACK and FIN flags enabled to both the source and destination hosts. This will apparently cause the TCP/IP stacks of both the source and destination hosts to try to acknowledge that the peer side wants to close the connection and will therefore both send ACK packets.

As a result, a continious loop of ACK packet traffic between the source and destination hosts will occur. This causes a significant increase in network traffic. It also may cause the source and destination service to crash. 

A demonstration exploit Win32 binary is available at:

http://195.244.37.241/mimsc.zip
Impact': A remote user can cause a significant increase in network traffic and can cause the service using the TCP connection to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows 98 Operating System Can Be Crashed When Running a Web Server or Other Servers And the AUX Device is Accessed By the Program
Version(s): tested on Windows 98 (first edition) *with* CON\CON kernel patch
Description:
It is reported that when programs running on Windows 98 access the AUX device, CPU usage will increase to 100% and, in most cases, the operating system will crash.
It is reported that some applications (such as some web servers) will filter requests for the AUX device so that the read request will not occur (and the system will not crash).  However, many applications do not filter or do not properly filter these requests.  Some FTP applications that do not properly filter these requests reportedly include:

BisonFTP V4R1
Broker FTP Server 5.9.5.0
G6 FTP Server v2.15 (AKA BulletProof FTP Server)
GuildFTPD 0.922
SurgeFTP 2.0f
WarFTPD 1.71
WFTPD 3.00 R5
Impact': A remote user can cause the Windows 98 operating system to crash by requesting that the server (e.g., FTP server, web server) access the AUX device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows NT 4.0 RPC Input Validation Failure Lets Remote Users Destabilize the Operating System
Version(s): Windows 2000, Windows NT 4.0
Description:
Microsoft reported that Bindview discovered a vulnerability in the RPC servers associated with several products, including Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows NT 4.0 operating systems. The security hole allows a remote user to send a malformed RPC message to the server potentially causing the operating system to become unstable. 
It is reported that one or more RPC servers used by Windows 2000 and Windows NT 4.0 fails to validate input received from an RPC stub (which is based on user-supplied data). If the data does not match the specifications in the stub's interface definition or if the data is otherwise out of range, the RPC server may behave unpredicatbly or may crash.

Similar flaws are contained in Microsoft SQL Server and Microsoft Exchange Server (see the separate Alerts for these other product vulnerabilities).
Impact': A remote user can send a malformed RPC message to Microsoft Windows 2000 or Windows NT 4.0 to cause it to become unstable.
Solution: The vendor has released patches. See the Vendor URL to obtain the latest patch information.

Title: Windows 2000 May Disclose Descriptive Information To Local Users Attempting Password Guessing with the NetUserChangePassword API
Description:
It is reported that the NetUserChangePassword API call in Windows 2000 may allow local users to conduct password guessing attempts against user accounts in any connected domain.
Under Windows 2000, it appears that this API function may be accessible to all users in the "Everyone" group.  The error responses are reportedly descriptive (ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED, ERROR_INVALID_PASSWORD, NERR_NotPrimary, NERR_UserNotFound), allowing a user to attempt to change another user's password and receive descriptive information about whether the account exists or not and, if it exists, whether the password is correct.
Impact': A local user conducting a password guessing attempt can receive descriptive information about other user account names and password validity on any connected domain.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Windows NT Lets Remote Users Cause Increased Packet Overhead and Increased CPU Resource Consumption
Version(s): NT 4
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in several operating systems that allows remote users to cause the host to transmit a significantly higher number of packets and consume increased CPU resources to do so, creating a potential denial of service condition.
In the TCP protocol, the initiating host specifies a Maximum Segment Size (MSS) value to request that the remote host send an amount of TCP data no larger than the MSS value in any single IP packet. The purpose is presumably to indicate the largest TCP segment that, if fragmented during transmission, can be reassembled by the initiating host. 

For Windows NT, the lowest value appears to be one. At such a low level, the remote host will send only one byte of data in each TCP segment, which results in a significant increase in packets transmitted (with large headers and a small payload) and in a significant increase in CPU resources consumed to participate in the TCP protocol with these values.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service by setting a low MSS value and then requesting a large amount of data. This will result in the remote host transmitting a significantly higher number of packets and TCP overhead than would normally be sent and consuming increased CPU resources to do this.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (CIAC Issues Advisory L-101) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 LDAP Server Lets Remote Users Gain Administrator Access to the Domain Controller When Configured to Support LDAP over SSL
Description:
Microsoft has reported a vulnerability in Windows 2000 that affects customers running LDAP over SSL.  The security hole may allow a remote user to change any other user's domain login password, including that of a domain administrator.
The LDAP via SSL function reportedly contains a vulnerability that can be triggered only when the directory principal is a domain user and the LDAP data attribute is the domain password.  In this case, the function fails to properly check the permissions of the user making the LDAP request.

If a remote user exploits this vulnerability to change the password of a domain administrator, the remote user can gain administrative control of the domain server.

The vendor notes that the affected function can be accessed by any remote user that can connect to the LDAP server (including access via anonymous sessions).

Because LDAP over SSL sessions cannot be conducted unless the administrator has installed a digital certificate on the LDAP server, default installations of Windows  2000 are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can change the password of a domain administrator and gain administrative control of the domain controller server.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the patch.

Title: (Official Vendor Bulletin) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 LDAP Server Lets Remote Users Gain Administrator Access to the Domain Controller When Configured to Support LDAP over SSL
Description:
Microsoft has reported a vulnerability in Windows 2000 that affects customers running LDAP over SSL.  The security hole may allow a remote user to change any other user's domain login password, including that of a domain administrator.
The LDAP via SSL function reportedly contains a vulnerability that can be triggered only when the directory principal is a domain user and the LDAP data attribute is the domain password.  In this case, the function fails to properly check the permissions of the user making the LDAP request.

If a remote user exploits this vulnerability to change the password of a domain administrator, the remote user can gain administrative control of the domain server.

The vendor notes that the affected function can be accessed by any remote user that can connect to the LDAP server (including access via anonymous sessions).

Because LDAP over SSL sessions cannot be conducted unless the administrator has installed a digital certificate on the LDAP server, default installations of Windows  2000 are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can change the password of a domain administrator and gain administrative control of the domain controller server.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the patch.

Title: Microsoft Windows 2000 Allows Local Users to Elevate Privileges
Version(s): Win2K, Win2K SP1
Description:
Georgi Guninski reported a vulnerability in Microsoft Windows 2000 that allows local users to elevate their privileges.
It is reported that if a local user has permissions or capabilities to execute programs on a Windows 2000 system, then the user may obtain elevated privileges that will at least provide write access to C:\WINNT\SYSTEM32 and HKCR.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to the fact that the x86 debug registers DR0-7 are global for all processes.  As a result, a hardware breakpoint that is set in one process will affect other processes and services.  

If hardware breakpoint in a service is triggered and then followed by an unhandled single step exception, the process or service will be terminated.  It then becomes possible for a local user to hijack the terminated proecesses trusted named pipes.  When a different process or service writes to the hijacked named pipe, the local user can then impersonate the terminated service.

Demonstration exploit code can reportedly be obtained from:
http://www.guninski.com/pipe3.cpp
Impact': A local user can elevate their privileges, at least to the level where the local user can obtain write access to C:\WINNT\SYSTEM32 and HKCR.
Solution: The vendor reportedly indicates that SP2 fixes this vulnerability.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 Indexing Service Allows Remote Users to View Include Programming Files
Version(s): Indexing Service in Windows 2000 Server, Advanced Server, and Datacenter Server
Description:
Microsoft announced a vulnerability in the Indexing Service function of Windows 2000 that allows remote users to view certain files on the web server.
This vulnerability is reported to be a new variant of the  Malformed Hit-Highlighting  vulnerability discussed in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-006 (http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/MS00-006.asp).  It allows a remote user to view certain "include" programming files that reside on the web server.

Microsoft reports that the Index Service filter that implements the hit-highlighting (also known as "WebHits") functionality does not adequately constrain what files can be requested.  If a remote user provides a malformed argument in a request to hit-highlight a document, it is possible to escape the virtual directory and obtain include files.  The vendor reports that there are no other known types of files that can accessed.
Impact': A remote user can read "include" programming files that reside on the web server.
Solution: The vendor has released a patch.  See the Source Message or the Vendor URL for details.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Microsoft Index Server for NT Can Be Crashed By Local Users, Allows Local Users to Execute Arbitrary Code With System Level Privileges, and Lets Remote Users View Certain Include Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Microsoft warned of two vulnerabilities in its Index Server 2.0 for NT.  The first security hole allows local users to crash the server and, in a more complicated situation, may let local users executed arbitrary code with local system privileges.  In addition, a separate vulnerability allows remote users to view "include" files.
The first vulnerability is a buffer overflow in a function that processes search requests. If a local user provides an overly long value for for a particular search parameter, the vulnerability can be triggered.  The result may be a crash that causes the Index Server to fail.  If a specially crafted search parameter is provided, the result may be that the local user's arbitrary code is executed on the server with system level privleges (run in the Local System security context).

The second vulnerability is reported to be a new variant of the "Malformed Hit-Highlighting" vulnerability discussed in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-006
(http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/MS00-006.asp).  In this case, the remote user can view "include" files residing on the web server. 

Microsoft notes that Index Server 2.0 is not part of NT's default configuration.
Impact': A local user can cause the Index Server to crash or may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server with system privileges.  A remote user can view "include" programming files on the web server.
Solution: Microsoft has released a patch.  See the Source Message for more information or the Vendor URL for complete details.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Microsoft Windows 2000 Domain Controllers Can Be Effectively Halted By Remote Users
Version(s): Windows 2000 Server, Windows 2000 Advanced Server, Windows 2000 Datacenter Server
Description:
Microsoft and Defcom Labs report a vulnerability in a core service running on all Windows 2000 domain controllers that allows a remote user to cause the server to consume all memory and effectively stop processing of further request.
Defcom Labs reports that the vulnerability exists in the Kerberos service and Kerberos password service and that a successful exploit can make all domain authentication impossible.

It is reported that by creating a connection to the Kerberos service and then disconnecting without reading from the socket, a memory leak in the LSA subsystem will be triggered.  After approximately 4000 connections of this nature, the Kerberos service will stop accepting connections to tcp ports 88 (kerberos) and 464 (kpasswd) and all domain authentication will effectively have died.

It requires a reboot to recover from the attack.
Impact': A remote user could repeatedly send certain invalid service requests to the target server causing all available memory on the server to be depleted. If enough memory is depleted, the domain controller could become unresponsive.  As a result, the domain controller would no longer process logon requests or issue new Kerberos tickets until it is rebooted.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for the complete vendor advisory.

Title: Microsoft Windows Me Operating System and Windows 98 with the Plus! 98 Package Disclose Data Compression Passwords
Description:
Microsoft issued a security bulletin (MS01-019) describing a vulnerability in the Plus! 98 package for Windows 98 and in the Windows Me operating system that could disclose data compression passwords to local users.
According to the vendor, Plus! 98, which is an optional package for Windows 98 and Windows 98 Second Edition, and the Windows Me operating system both include a data compression feature called "Compressed Folders."  This feature provides a password protection option for folders that have been compressed.  The feature contains a flaw that records passwords used to protect the compressed folders in a file on the host (c:\windows\dynazip.log).
Impact': A local user could obtain data compression passwords.  If networking is enabled, a remote user could obtain data compression passwords.
Solution: See the vendor URL for information on how to fix this problem.

Title: Microsoft's Dr. Watson Diagnostic Utility May Reveal Passwords and Other Sensitive Information
Version(s): Windows NT 4.0 (All service packs), Windows 2000 (Release and SP1), Probably Windows NT 3.5x but untested
Description:
Microsoft's Dr. Watson utility, which is part of Windows NT and Windows 2000, uses improper access permissions on one of its output files that allows local user to potentially obtain passwords and other sensitive information.
When a user-mode program crashes under Windows NT and Windows 2000, Dr. Watson is displays a system error dialog and captures a snapshot of the process space and saves it for debugging purposes to a file called "user.dmp".

The default location in NT for user.dmp is world-readable.  On NT4 systems, the default location is %SystemRoot%\user.dmp, which will usually end up being C:\WINNT\user.dmp.  Default permissions on NT4 systems give Everyone Full Control on the WINNT directory.

Windows 2000 is also vulnerable, but in fewer circumstances.  The Windows 2000 default location for user.dmp is C:\Documents and Settings\All
Users\Documents\DrWatson\user.dmp.  This location is world-readable by all users but is not world-writable.

Because crash dump files may contain passwords and other sensitive information that had been stored in memory just prior to a crash, this file can be exploited.

This was originally reported by No Strezzz Cazzz.  Please note that prior discussions on this may be available on the NTBugtraq mailing list.

The source report contains some additional exploit information.
Impact': A local user could view passwords and other sensitive information.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The source report contains a potential workaround.

Title: A Microsoft German-Language Hotfix for Windows NT 4 Incorrectly Displays Some Security Events as Other Security Events
Version(s): MSAuditE.dll Version 4.0.1381.7086
Description:
A bug has been reported in the German version of a Microsoft Hotfix for NT 4 that results in certain security events being displayed incorrectly as other events.  The hotfix was in response to Microsoft Security Bulletin (MS00-070), titled "Patch Available for Multiple LPC and LPC Ports Vulnerabilities."
Hotfix archive gerq266433i.exe reportedly includes the file MSAuditE.dll, version 4.0.1381.7086 from 08.11.2000, that contains a broken message table for security events.  It contains a new security event 519 but does not contain a resource string for this event.  As a result, certain security events (519 through 644) are interpreted and displayed incorrectly as other events.

A more thorough German-language description can be found at http://www.heysoft.de/Warnung.htm

The vendor has been notified.
Impact': Certain security events are displayed incorrectly as other security events.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor plans to correct the situation.

Title: Windows 2000's WINMM.DLL Can Locally Crash WINLOGIN.EXE
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
The "MM Notify Callback" message can apparently be used via winmm.dll to crash winlogon.exe.  This must be performed locally.
It is reported that, similar to the recent "NetDDE Agent" window vulnerability, there is another vulnerable window hosted by winlogon.exe: "MM Notify Callback". It is hosted by winmm.dll which is loaded into winlogon.exe.
Impact': Winlogon can be locally crashed, preventing future login attempts.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Internet Explorer, Outlook, and Other HTML-based Applications May Crash Due to Error in MSHTML.DLL HTML Parser
Description:
Applications that use the Microsoft DLL MSHTML.DLL for HTML parsing, such as Internet Explorer and Outlook, may crash when multiple window objects are open and one object is receiving data.
According to the report, the bug is only experienced when dealing with multiple window objects, where one is receiving data. To reproduce the bug, you can create a JScript object, set a property on the object from the window object receiving data, delete the object and create it again.  The author states that no exploitable buffer overflows have been found so far.

The author provided the following demonstration code:

------------InstantCrash.html-----------------
<iframe id=test style="display:none"></iframe>
<script>
Larholm = {}; // Object literal
test.document.open(); // Stream data
test.document.write("<s"+"cript>top.Larholm.test=0</s"+"cript>");
delete Larholm;
Larholm = {}; // Crash
</script>
----------------------------------------------
Impact': Malicious HTML code could cause the HTML application to crash.
Solution: As a workaround, you can disable active scripting.  Vendor will fix in an upcoming service pack for Internet Explorer.
